paragraph.value: Table 2 compares the accuracy of our model on the test data with two baselines and two state-of-the-art comparable systems. The MT baseline simply consists of the accuracy of the mt sentences with respect to the pe ground truth. The other baseline is given by a statistical PE (SPE) system (Simard et al., 2007) chosen by the WMT17 organizers. Table 2 shows that when our model is trained with only the
WMT17 official training sentences, it cannot even approach the baselines. Even when the
WMT16 sentences are added, its accuracy is still well below that of the baselines. However, when the
artificial data are added, it reports a major improvement and it outperforms them both
. In addition, we have compared our model with two recent systems that have used our  same training settings (
BLEU p.p. over (Varis and Bojar, 2017) and

BLEU p.p. over (BÂ´erard et al., 2017)). Since their models explicitly predicts edit operations rather than post-edited sentences, we speculate that these two tasks are of comparable intrinsic complexity.
